docs.lead_paragraph: Recent studies find that genes may not be so important in determining how long someone will live.

headline.main: Live Long? Die Young? Answer Isn’t Just in Genes
headline.print_headline: Live Long? Die Young? Answer Isn’t Just in Genes

docs.snippet: Recent studies find that genes may not be so important in determining how long someone will live.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Stems Cells Without Embryo Loss'' (editorial, Aug. 26): You say that the negative reaction of religious conservatives to an innovative new way to produce embryonic stem cells without destroying embryos demonstrates ''why the government should avoid making decisions on theological grounds.''

headline.main: Gray Areas in Stem Cell Research

docs.abstract: Four letters comment on Aug 26 editorial about new technique of extracting stem cells without destroying embryo; David Allison says there will always be some gray area where theology and sectarian moral philosophy overlap; Peter Bouteneff, professor of dogmatic theology at St Vladimir's Orthodox Seminary, says recent advance in stem cell research is big step, but does not obviate conflict over issue; James Siegel says only when citizens demand to be led by secular data can Americans expect officials to give up holier-than-thou politicking; David Goldstein says stem cell research will continue despite religious conservatives but at slower pace

docs.lead_paragraph: Since he left office, Bill Clinton has made a lasting mark in a cause that he came to only late in his presidency.

headline.main: Clinton Makes Up for Lost Time in Battling AIDS
headline.print_headline: Clinton Makes Up for Lost Time in Battling AIDS

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary V. Relling advocates pharmacogenetics, the use of high-tech genetic testing to custom-make drugs to patients’ individual needs.

headline.kicker: A Conversation With Mary V. Relling

docs.snippet: Mary V. Relling advocates pharmacogenetics, the use of high-tech genetic testing to custom-make drugs to patients’ individual needs.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Mary V. Relling's office in St. Jude Children's Research Hospital sits a small ceramic statue of St. Jude Thaddeus, the patron saint of impossible causes. Dr. Relling, the head of the department of pharmaceutical sciences at St. Jude, has a fondness for impossible causes.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Mary V. Relling; Saving Lives With Tailor-Made Medication

docs.abstract: Mary V Relling, St Jude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, pharmaceutical sciences department head, discusses practice of pharmacogenetics, clinical discipline in which doctors tailor drugs for patients based on genetic information; describes why pharmaceutical companies are not supportive of plan to tailor drugs for patients; works primarily with children's illness; photo (M)
